曹操要想成就“霸王之业”，只须“守位以财”。这句话也是当代国际关系中永恒的真谛：要想成为世界霸主，必须有最强势的经济！曹操“守位以财”的方法，在历史上叫作“屯田”。 所谓“屯田”，就是招募流民开垦无主荒地，是典型的空手套白狼：曹操之所以能招募流民，是因为流民相信他能保护自己安心生产；曹操之所以能保护流民，是因为他身后有众多流民。 “鸡生蛋，蛋生鸡”的道理大家都知道，关键是第一只蛋——第一笔招募流民的钱究竟要从哪里来？ 乱世之中，无论增加税收（财政政策）还是铸造大钱（货币政策）都不好使。大家都快饿死了，增加税收肯定捞不到油水；至于铸大钱，就算有人肯要，也没有粮食可卖。 既然征税和铸大钱都骗不到财富，那就无须遮遮掩掩，直接明火执仗地抢劫好了！ 定都许都之后，曹操收编的第一批黄巾军是青州流民，大约有一百万人。为了安抚这批流民，曹操挑选了其中的精壮者，号“青州兵”。然后，曹操亲自带着青州兵劫掠了从汝南、颍川来的黄巾军，夺得了自己的“第一桶金”。 靠着这些资财，建安元年（公元196年），曹操颁布《置屯田令》。流民每五十人为一屯，春夏耕种、冬秋操练。屯民如果使用官家耕牛（也是抢来的），收成与官家四六分成；屯民如果自备耕牛，则收成与官家五五分成。
==========
中国是部金融史 (陈雨露)
- Your Highlight at location 2638-2640 | Added on Wednesday, 20 April 2022 17:28:23

真实的世界永远不会如此纯净，在一个所谓“自由”的市场里，士族亦官亦商，他们会以种种手段掠夺农民的土地，可能是强买强卖，可能是巧取豪夺，可能是暴力抢占，唯一不可能的就是经济赎买。如果以公平的经济赎买来交换农民的土地，这个官当着还有什么意思？
==========
中国是部金融史 (陈雨露)
- Your Highlight at location 2905-2912 | Added on Wednesday, 20 April 2022 17:36:22

……西晋士族兴盛→士族皇族内耗、八王之乱→五胡乱华…… 在这些循环中，我看到了一条无比清晰的运动轨迹：封建集权→货币官铸→击溃异族→经济衰退。集权必然导致强势封建集权，也就一定能集中全国资源对抗游牧民族，强势帝王又怎么可能容忍游牧民族在自己的地盘上闲庭信步？只不过，强势的封建集权一定要靠封建官僚才能实现，借此，封建官僚壮大，小农经济在短暂辉煌之后又会陷入长久的沉寂。 吃此一堑，帝国又必然转向另一种统治模式：封建分权→货币私铸→经济兴盛→异族入侵→丧失半壁江山！分权必然伴随着封建统治者的衰落，既然封建统治者无法干预经济，经济也就获得了成长空间。只不过，封建集权衰败的同时，一定会为游牧民族入侵留出空间，中原大地可能陷入长久的战乱之中。
==========
中国是部金融史 (陈雨露)
- Your Highlight at location 3407-3409 | Added on Wednesday, 20 April 2022 21:45:33

中国古代经济自然演进中最合理的单一货币重量既不是西汉官定的五铢钱，也不是民间私铸的鹅眼钱，而是隋五铢。这个标准的确立有赖于隋文帝放开了市场，废黜了盐铁专营，对民间放开了所有工商业渠道。天下只有一种人不能做生意，那就是封建官僚。
==========
中国是部金融史 (陈雨露)
- Your Highlight at location 3533-3536 | Added on Wednesday, 20 April 2022 21:55:53

修建运河并不必然导致国家败亡，也可以激发财富创造力。一千二百年后，美国第一条运河伊利运河通航，当时联邦政府穷得要命，根本拿不出修运河的钱。于是，美国政府成立了运河公司，向公众放开了投资渠道，每一个普通人都可以购买运河公司的股票。结果，不但没有闹出任何乱子，还激发了美国历史上新一轮股票市场狂潮。
==========
中国是部金融史 (陈雨露)
- Your Highlight at location 4163-4173 | Added on Thursday, 21 April 2022 11:12:09

不是所有的竞争都一定提高生产效率，不是所有的竞争都一定会提高社会公众福利，更不是所有市场选择的结果都一定是好的！在这个世界上，除了“竞争”（compete）还有“竞次”（race to the bottom），“竞争”是比谁更优秀，“竞次”是比谁更下贱、谁脸皮更厚、谁心更黑！ “竞争”和“竞次”也是有相同点的，那就是，两者都把市场作为工具，都通过市场实现利益分配和再分配。所有社会都存在市场，市场也都有“竞次”特征，只不过封建社会时的表现更为突出。马克思在描述资本主义社会的时候提出，资本家对劳动力的剥削是有底线的：维持劳动力再生产，工人工资要足以维持自身和家庭生存。封建社会不存在这条底线，失去土地的流民只能压低自身劳动力的价格，甚至被迫损害生命，结果还是不能获得维持自身和家庭生存的资源。 人们竞相出卖自己，微薄的收入最后一定会突破马克思所谓的“剥削底线”，不要说购买土地，就连自己和家人的生存都难以为继。最后，人们只能卖身为奴，让自己从封建社会直接倒退回奴隶社会。所以，我们才在史籍中一次次见到“父子携手，共入江湖”的描写。
==========
中国是部金融史 (陈雨露)
- Your Highlight at location 4248-4253 | Added on Thursday, 21 April 2022 11:17:44

通货膨胀，富人手里的债务会越来越不值钱，穷人手里的钱只能买到更少的东西。 所以，通货膨胀对富人有利。 看到这些，大家千万不要以为通货紧缩就一定对穷人有利，穷人手中的货币确实增值了，实际上，富人控制的货币更多。而且，通货紧缩会提高所有人的赚钱难度，直接降低所有人的生产积极性，毕竟现在赚钱少了——虽然只是名义上的。 所以，无论通胀、通缩，都有利于富人，不利于穷人——规则永远是强者的规则。
==========
中国是部金融史 (陈雨露)
- Your Highlight at location 4259-4265 | Added on Thursday, 21 April 2022 11:19:27

所有的货币手段都是中性的，关键是，增加的货币究竟给谁？ 第一个方法，把新增货币集中发放给强势阶层，也就是封建官僚。无论是把新铸造的铜钱直接拨给封建官僚，还是以朝廷的名义借钱给这些人，其实结果都是一样的。很遗憾，对这些人增发货币并不能刺激经济，反而会造成经济停滞、物价上涨。原因很简单，货币不掌握在创造财富的人手里。 第二个方法，把新增货币集中发放给弱势阶层，就是原本穷困的黎民百姓。也许没有理由直接给现钱，也许编造一个名头然后再给钱，也许拿钱随便买点穷人的什么东西……只有这样的货币增发才能真正刺激内需，启动经济复苏之源。因为，普通人需要购买的东西太多了！
==========
中国是部金融史2：天下之财 (陈雨露，杨忠恕 著)
- Your Highlight at location 89-92 | Added on Thursday, 21 April 2022 11:40:26

家庭，最终成为流民。 　　整个财富循环的逻辑是：“耕者有其田”、放开经济管制→经济井喷式发展→封建官僚崛起→“官商”兼并土地→小农成为流民→帝国崩溃，最终的结果：国弱、民贫，唯独官富。在中国漫长的历史中，大汉帝国是这个循环的肇始者，却并非循环的终结者，此后历朝历代无一不陷入如是的怪圈之中。
==========
中国是部金融史2：天下之财 (陈雨露，杨忠恕 著)
- Your Highlight at location 89-92 | Added on Thursday, 21 April 2022 11:40:33

中国是部金融史2：天下之财 (陈雨露，杨忠恕 著)
- Your Highlight at location 250-252 | Added on Friday, 22 April 2022 10:47:05

如果土地是最值钱的东西，就一定要抑制兼并，因为，兼并土地就等于抢劫财富，抑制兼并就等于抑制官家豪强抢夺财富。这个问题也可以反过来说，如果土地不是值钱的东西，也就没有必要抑制土地兼并。 　　土地不值钱，那什么最值钱？ 　　创新，创新技术、创新产品、创新行业，这才是最值钱的

Why Smart People Make Big Money Mistakes and How to Correct Them: Lessons From the Life-Changing Science of Behavioral Economics (Belsky, Gary)
- Your Highlight at location 391-394 | Added on Monday, 25 April 2022 17:48:36

Twice in recent years, the government has tried to stimulate economic activity by giving people tax rebates. There is considerable evidence that the programs did not work as well as intended on either occasion, and calling the checks “rebates” may have been part of the problem. As Epley describes it, “Reimbursements send people on trips to the bank. Bonuses send people on trips to the Bahamas.”
==========
Why Smart People Make Big Money Mistakes and How to Correct Them: Lessons From the Life-Changing Science of Behavioral Economics (Belsky, Gary)
- Your Highlight at location 387-389 | Added on Monday, 25 April 2022 17:48:48

84 percent of those whose $25 was framed as a “bonus” spent some or all of it, but only 21 percent of students who had their $25 described as a “rebate” opened their wallets.

多用名词，少用动词
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 237-239 | Added on Sunday, 1 May 2022 18:09:56

对比“我是个巧克力爱好者”和“我吃很多巧克力”这两种说法，前者更能影响人们对巧克力的偏爱程度。“爱好者”是个名词，“吃”是个动词。说“我是个巧克力爱好者”的人，使用名词而非动词，表现出对巧克力更强烈的偏好。
==========

要让人们做某件事，先保证自己正在做（因为他们会模仿你）。
==========

- Your Highlight at location 508-510 | Added on Sunday, 1 May 2022 18:36:45

有一个非常简单的方法可以让人们信任你。你只需要触发催产素的释放即可。那该怎么做呢？最简单的方法就是向对方展示你对他们的信任。如果你做了某件事表明你信任某人，对方也更可能反过来信任你。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 511-516 | Added on Sunday, 1 May 2022 18:37:09

那么，你怎样向别人表明你对他们的信任呢？方法很多。这里有一些例子： ·请他们做一件你通常会自己做的重要任务，放手让他们做。 ·把你公寓的钥匙给别人，让他们在你不在家的时候代为照料宠物，或者给植物浇水。 ·让他们借你的车。 ·请他们在一次重要会议上做报告。 当你采取行动表明信任某人，获得信任的人会释放催产素。反过来，这又可能提高他们对你的信任感。
==========

- Your Highlight at location 623-628 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 12:32:56

·手掌向上摊开的意思是，你在向受众提出邀请。 ·双手摊开，手掌呈45度，表明你诚实、坦率。 ·双手摊开，手掌向下，意味着你对自己正在说的事情很确定。 ·双手呈90度，手指并拢，表明你对自己所说的事情自信，且拥有专业知识。 ·手摸脸、头发或脖子，会让你显得紧张或犹豫不决，手交叉放在胸前也一样。 ·双手叉腰站着，暗示你的攻击性很强。有时候采用这样的姿态也是合适的（比如在谈判上），但使用之前务必三思。

- Your Highlight at location 939-944 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 12:56:15

·我们采访的客户里有75%…… ·只有15%的客户回应了调查，这暗示…… 但这种基于数据的方法，说服力没有故事和轶事强。就算你希望收录数据，但如果能聚焦于一件或多件轶事，比如，“来自旧金山的玛丽小姐分享了她使用我们产品的故事……”接着便讲述玛丽的故事，你的陈述会有更为强大的影响力。 策略29 如果你用故事的形式来传递你的支持性信息和数据，人们更有可能按你的要求去做。
==========

- Your Highlight at location 1005-1008 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 13:03:01

这个团体里的人，他认识得越多，就越容易预见到存在什么样的人格面具，并据此改变自己的信息、故事和陈述。他对团体中的人越是不了解，就越是只能猜测可能存在什么样的人格面具。杰弗里不太可能在同一场陈述里激活四种甚至更多种人格面具，但他肯定可以对陈述进行合理安排，激活两种甚至三种人格面具，如果他想要实现最大的筹款可能性、最高的筹款额度，他无疑应该这么做。
==========

- Your Highlight at location 992-994 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 13:03:34

他可以先举出本地商业团体向其他类似慈善组织捐赠的例子，加强自己的陈述。这么做能提醒商人们想到第一种人格面具。提起类似的捐款，讲述需要帮助的人的故事，杰弗里将激活“伸出援助之手”的人格面具。这样，等他请求捐赠的时候，商人们答应的概率会更大，给出的捐款说不定也更多。
==========

- Your Highlight at location 1029-1033 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 15:07:05

苹果公司推出了iPod。孩子们游说我们给他们买iPod，我们买了。由于我是一个“精通技术的用户”，我买了一台MP3播放器，但我没有买iPod。iPod是苹果公司生产的，我的人格面具不适合做苹果的粉丝，但我的MP3播放器很难用。iPod很酷，我的MP3播放器又丑又没法用。所以，我买了一台iPod。当我打破自己“不用苹果、全用个人计算机”的人格面具，买了一款苹果产品的时候，我扎扎实实地感受到了一丝不和谐的刺痛
==========

- Your Highlight at location 1091-1092 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 15:10:24

要让人们做某件事，可以使用现有人格面具作为锚点来创建相关的新人格面具
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 1082-1089 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 15:10:52

你可以使用某人现有的人格面具作为锚点，更轻松地从中创造出新的人格面具。你可以提出一个能激活现有人格面具的请求，等当事人同意之后，再提出一个符合你想要创建的人格面具的请求。以下是一些配对人格面具的例子： ·现有人格面具：“我是一个关注自己身体的人。” ·容易创建的新人格面具：“我是一个关注儿童健康的人。” ·现有人格面具：“我是一个节俭的人。” ·容易创建的新人格面具：“我是一个投票支持削减政府债务的人。” ·现有人格面具：“我是一个富有创造力的人。” ·容易创建的新人格面具：“我是一个喜欢尝试新鲜事物的人。”
==========

- Your Highlight at location 1235-1240 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 15:30:43

休息结束后，我关掉音乐，关上门。 刺激1（导师说“好啦，让我们回到刚才说的地方”）→反应（人们就座并安静下来） 接着我们加入： 刺激1（导师说“好啦，让我们回到刚才说的地方”）+刺激2（音乐关上，导师关上门）→反应（人们就座并安静下来） 于是我们得到： 刺激2（音乐关上，导师关上门）→反应（人们就座并安静下来）

。大多数的赌场游戏都采用了可变比率方案。玩家拉动老虎机的操纵杆10次，获得一次奖励，接着又拉动了52次，才得到下一次奖励。

- Your Highlight at location 1313-1317 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 15:40:30

乔治开了一间实验室，政府会来检查。他知道检查员会来，但不知道什么时候来。可能是这个月来，也可能是3个月或者6个月后来。检查员喜欢突击检查。 所以，乔治决定，他最好是确保实验室始终符合所有要求，这样检查员来的时候，他就能得到“优秀”评定。本例中，遵照所有规章要求是期望行为，获得“优秀”评定则是强化。 检查员一定会来，但时间间隔不可预测，不固定。这就是可变间隔方案。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 1327-1331 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 15:44:08

假设你有一家咖啡馆，并为顾客设计了老顾客优惠卡。顾客每买10杯咖啡，就可得到一杯免费咖啡。每次买咖啡时，顾客都要在自己的优惠卡上盖章。这就是固定比率方案。 研究告诉我们，这将带来行为的高发（顾客会在短时间内买很多杯咖啡，好填满优惠卡），等他得到免费咖啡后，将出现平静期，行为出现的频率变少（也就是说，他从这家咖啡馆买的咖啡减少了）。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 1331-1340 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 15:44:40

越是接近目标，人的动力越强 对于人们达到目标后产生的懈怠感，你没有什么对付的法子。你可以让他们从头开始（再给他们一张空白优惠卡，积攒咖啡戳），也可以让他们拥有另一种选择，获得更好的奖励。不过，你可以采取一定措施来加速他们的行为。 冉·吉维兹（Ran Kivetz，2006）做了一项有关老顾客咖啡优惠券的实验。他给了一些人A类卡，给了另一些人B类卡。 ·A类卡有10个方框积攒优惠戳；参与者拿到卡片时，所有的方框都是空白的。 ·B类卡有12个方框积攒优惠戳；参与者拿到卡片时，前两个方框已经盖好了优惠戳。 顾客把优惠卡盖满戳记会花多长时间？A类卡和B类卡分别用了多长时间？不管使用哪种卡，参与者都必须购买10杯咖啡才能获得免费咖啡。那么，卡的不同会带来不同的行为吗？ 答案显然是肯定的。获得B类卡的人比获得A类卡的人能更快地填满卡片，尽管两种卡片都需要10杯咖啡才能通关。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 1410-1412 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 15:47:49

·立刻给予强化。如果行为和强化之间相隔太久，那么，你或许是在强化某种不同的东西。人们对强化的反应是无意识的，如果凯蒂等了两个小时才跟乔安妮聊天，乔安妮就不会将强化与行为联系起来。
==========

- Your Highlight at location 1384-1385 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 15:48:05

对连续推进的行为给予区别性强化。”我们知道，根据操作性条件反射原理，任何得到强化的行为都会增加。但如果你在尝试建立一种新行为，你没法强化它，所以你必须先强化能带来你想要的行为之前的行为。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 1392-1404 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 15:48:09

开始，每当出现洗手机会，凯蒂就跑到乔安妮身边。 凯蒂会一直等着，直到看到乔安妮走向洗手池。乔安妮一朝着洗手池走，凯蒂就开始微笑着跟乔安妮说话。起初，乔安妮只是随意地朝着洗手池移动，但这没关系。如果乔安妮真的走到洗手池边，凯蒂会微笑，并赞许乔安妮做的某件事，比如她刚才处理最后一个病人的表现有多么好。凯蒂知道乔安妮喜欢赞许和聊天，而这两件事将对乔安妮形成有效的强化。凯蒂这样做了几天，直到走向洗手池这一行为建立起来。 2.凯蒂开始寻找连续塑造中的下一个行为，也就是乔安妮不光要走向洗手池，还要实际接触它。 在定下新塑造要求的第一天，当乔安妮走向洗手池，凯蒂什么也没说。但等到乔安妮摸了摸洗手池，凯蒂便微笑着称赞了她。凯蒂对触摸洗手池的行为给予了好几天的回应。 3.连续塑造的最后一部分是让乔安妮真正洗手，所以凯蒂不再因为乔安妮触碰洗手池而给予赞许并与之交谈。 她安静地等着乔安妮真正打开水龙头，往手上涂肥皂的那一刻。只要乔安妮拿起肥皂，凯蒂就会微笑着去跟她聊天，并适当称赞。凯蒂还会继续做上几天，确保乔安妮洗手的行为建立起来。
==========

- Your Highlight at location 1525-1529 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 15:53:18

·A广告公司以“做最好的自己”为主题展开广告宣传活动。它的内容主要是保持健康，保持匀称的身材，享受家人朋友的陪伴，在自己的余生做自己喜欢的活动。它包含了许多积极、健康、富有魅力的五六十岁人士的图片。 ·B广告公司提出的广告宣传活动以“再小心也不为过”为主题。它的内容是避免急性、慢性疾病。这一活动包含了一些积极、健康、富有魅力的五六十岁人士的图片，但还有更多身患重病、奄奄一息的人的图片。
==========

- Your Highlight at location 1535-1537 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 17:08:50

唤起人们对损失的恐惧，是让人们做事的一种方法。对任何的损失，我们的本能都十分地警觉和厌恶，因此在潜意识里，我们基于对损失的恐惧而采取行动的动力，远大于基于对收益的预期而采取行动的动力
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 1560-1566 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 17:09:04

巴里·施瓦茨（Barry Schwartz，2005）研究了人们的购车行为。参与者试驾了配备了全部选配项目的汽车。 ·在一种情况下，他们看到了配备全部选配项目的汽车的价格。如果他们说价格太贵，研究人员就请他们取消一部分选配项目以降低价格。 ·在另一种情况下，他们会看到汽车的基本价格（不带选配项目），以及每一选配项目的介绍和价格。他们可以选择自己想要加上的项目，每加一项，车价也相应提高。 在第一种情况下，参与者花的钱更多。在完整地体验了汽车之后，他们不愿意失去自己感觉（在某种意义上）已经拥有的东西
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 1567-1571 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 17:09:28

我们对损失有一种天然的恐惧，甚至连说话的措辞方式都能对此产生很大影响。 他引用了医学领域的研究。研究显示，如果病人听说，“如果你接受这种治疗，你有90%的机会活下来”，病人会选择这一治疗。 可要是病人听说，“如果你接受这种治疗，你有10%的死亡概率”，那么，病人选择此种治疗的可能性会大大降低。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 1590-1591 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 17:10:19

如果你希望人们重视你的产品或服务，就要让它变得稀缺或难以获得。
==========

如果你想理解掌控的重要性，请花上一个小时来观察一个一岁的小孩子，看看他怎样努力靠自己站起来或走路，看看他怎样玩拼图或者其他玩具。所有人，不管是成年人还是儿童，都有掌控的欲望。想要掌握技能或控制身边的环境，是一种普遍的人类动力。人有动力想要掌握一项运动、一款电子游戏，或是诸如焊接、手术、弹钢琴等技能

- Your Highlight at location 1806-1808 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 17:51:13

持弹爵士钢琴。好的老师知道怎样把知识或技能分解成小块。好的老师是掌控的大师。知道怎样针对具体的学生，把技能和信息分成大小合适的片段，是好老师的职责所在。而这是用掌控欲激励人的关键。你需要找到合适的挑战量来激发自己的掌控欲，如果挑战量过头，就会压垮人的掌控欲。

明确“做对了还是做错了”
==========

- Your Highlight at location 1843-1846 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 17:57:40

上面的反馈（“你没有彻底清理滤网。所有的残渣都要洗干净。现在再试一次”）中包括了说明。如果杰罗姆只说，“你没有彻底清理滤网”，那么，他告诉凯瑟琳她做得不对，但却没有给出任何解释。简短的解释（“所有的残渣都要洗干净”）就是说明
==========

- Your Highlight at location 1851-1852 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 17:57:56

你兴许认为，立刻给出反馈是最好的，但事实恐怕并非如此。如果一项任务包含若干小步骤，那么，最好等到做事的人完成所有步骤后，再对整个任务给出反馈
==========

- Your Highlight at location 1833-1835 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 17:58:06

==========

- Your Highlight at location 1856-1858 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 17:58:21

不要把表扬和反馈掺和到一起 反馈要客观。记住，掌控与内在动力有关，而与强化无关。人们不需要你的表扬来继续往下做，切换到表扬，会让人的焦点从内在动机偏离到外在动机上。它实际上反而可能会削弱掌控欲
==========

- Your Highlight at location 1861-1864 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 17:58:48

如果杰罗姆说，“你没有彻底清理滤网。所有的残渣都要洗干净。不过，这是你第一次做，干得不错。你真的掌握窍门了！现在再试一次。” 第二种方式将反馈和表扬掺和到了一起。这或许会让杰罗姆感觉不错，但凯瑟琳恐怕要犯糊涂。她清理得正确还是不正确呢？ 知道什么时候给予反馈，是好老师和不怎么好的老师之间的一大区别。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 1878-1880 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 17:59:26

有具体的、明确的、可实现的目标 不管是什么活动，只要有着具体的目标，心流状态就会出现
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 1880-1882 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 17:59:42

研究表明，为了进入并保持心流状态，我们需要感觉自己很有机会达成目标。如果我们认为自己很可能失败，就无法诱发心流状态。反过来说，要是活动的挑战性不够，它不能维持我们的专注度，心流状态会终止。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 1907-1918 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 18:01:18

这里有一些点子，可以鼓励人进入并保持心流状态。我们以杰夫为例： ·给人们布置一项有着可实现目标的具体任务。 告诉杰夫你想要他完成的事：你希望他为团队撰写一份白皮书和报告。告诉他你知道他以前从来没有写过这类文章，它可能很有挑战性，但你相信他能胜任。告诉他有关白皮书的具体要求，如长度，以及你希望何时完成。 ·让人们拥有尽量大的自主权，如，他们怎么完成任务，在哪里、在什么时候、跟谁一起完成。 你可以告知杰夫一些初始资源，或者对他说，如果碰到问题可以来找你，但要让他知道，怎样去展开研究由他自己拿主意。 ·人们着手做任务之后不要打扰。 每当你看到杰夫，要克制住自己，别去问他白皮书写得怎么样了。 ·创造反馈的机会，反馈最好是来自任务本身的。 杰夫可以判断自己在白皮书上是否有所进展，所以，他在做这项任务时自然会传回一些反馈。 如果你以这种方式设定任务，杰夫就有可能在撰写白皮书期间进入心流状态。如果当真如此，他会喜欢这项任务，并更有动力坚持下去，以后完成更多的白皮书。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 2031-2032 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 18:06:27

如果你希望人们与他人合作或帮助他人，那么不要提及金钱。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 2024-2026 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 18:08:00

经金钱启动的人更少请求别人帮助，也更少帮助别人，捐赠更少的钱，他们更喜欢独自工作或玩耍，在自己和他人之间留出更多的空间。
==========

8×7×6×5×4×3×2×1 阿莫斯·特沃斯基（Amos Tversky）和丹尼尔·卡尼曼（2011）在研究中询问人们这个问题，发现人们对上述数字的平均估计是2250。但是当他们以相反的顺序显示数字（1×2×3×4×5×6×7×8）时，平均值是512（顺便说一下，正确答案是40320）。从较大的数字8开始，跟从较小的数字1开始相比，前者得到的估计值要高得多

- Your Highlight at location 2069-2072 | Added on Monday, 2 May 2022 18:15:34

如果一家商店的广告说，顾客可以购买打折苏打水，但每名顾客只能买10瓶，那么人们就会比只说苏打水打折时购买更多的苏打水。以10作为上限，将10作为锚点。不提及数字时，0充当默认锚点。以10作为锚点，人们最终会购买比没有锚点时更多的苏打水。

说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 2194-2206 | Added on Tuesday, 3 May 2022 11:20:17

你可以打破这些偏误。你需要这样做： 1.提出你的听众已相信的事情并表示认同。 例如，你可以从市政委员会担心步行商业街会让人们难以在喜欢的商店附近找到停车位这一点着手。与其一开始就提出问题的解决办法，不如从他们相信的事情开始：“步行商业街占用了关键的停车位！没错！”你的听众可能会想：“正是如此！改成步行商业街之后就没法停车了。”现在，你在这一点上附和他们，他们会更有可能听你往下说。 2.引入认知失调。 认知失调指的是人们对持有互相矛盾的观点、意见或信念感到不舒服。本例中，你的听众认为步行商业街占用了停车位，停车位对商家很重要，如果你占用了停车位，就会减少生意。听众们并不认为这些想法互相矛盾，所以没有任何认知失调。 但接下来，你要向他们提供一份权威的研究，该研究表明，建有步行商业街的城镇，地方销售额提高了30%。这样一来，市政委员会就出现认知失调了。委员们希望提高销售额，但这跟他们认为步行商业街影响停车的看法不一致。 认知失调令人不舒服。市政委员会的委员们现在很不舒服。人们会采取行动来消除认知失调。 3.减少认知失调。 你先认同市政委员会的意见，接着引入了导致认知失调的研究数据。现在，你必须立刻说些什么，让委员们摆脱不舒服的认知失调。比方说，
==========

你可以打破这些偏误。你需要这样做： 1.提出你的听众已相信的事情并表示认同。 例如，你可以从市政委员会担心步行商业街会让人们难以在喜欢的商店附近找到停车位这一点着手。与其一开始就提出问题的解决办法，不如从他们相信的事情开始：“步行商业街占用了关键的停车位！没错！”你的听众可能会想：“正是如此！改成步行商业街之后就没法停车了。”现在，你在这一点上附和他们，他们会更有可能听你往下说。 2.引入认知失调。 认知失调指的是人们对持有互相矛盾的观点、意见或信念感到不舒服。本例中，你的听众认为步行商业街占用了停车位，停车位对商家很重要，如果你占用了停车位，就会减少生意。听众们并不认为这些想法互相矛盾，所以没有任何认知失调。 但接下来，你要向他们提供一份权威的研究，该研究表明，建有步行商业街的城镇，地方销售额提高了30%。这样一来，市政委员会就出现认知失调了。委员们希望提高销售额，但这跟他们认为步行商业街影响停车的看法不一致。 认知失调令人不舒服。市政委员会的委员们现在很不舒服。人们会采取行动来消除认知失调。 3.减少认知失调。 你先认同市政委员会的意见，接着引入了导致认知失调的研究数据。现在，你必须立刻说些什么，让委员们摆脱不舒服的认知失调。比方说，这时你可以指出，需要步行商业街来缓解当前的交通和停车拥堵。在当前的商业区，购物者有时候要无奈地把车停在三个街区之外，努力穿过交通繁忙的十字路口。交通拥堵是购物者的一大障碍。所以，步行商业街实际上能够解决交通拥堵问题，提升销售额。

- Your Highlight at location 2217-2219 | Added on Tuesday, 3 May 2022 11:21:10

碰到不确定状况就产生不适感，这种现象自有原因。研究人员观察了大脑在模棱两可或不确定期间的活动，发现杏仁核的活动增加（Hsu，2005）。杏仁核是处理情绪的地方。我们对不确定性的反应，跟身体受到威胁时的大脑模式相同：杏仁核活动增加。
==========

- Your Highlight at location 2364-2370 | Added on Tuesday, 3 May 2022 21:32:36

易卜拉欣·塞内（Ibrahim Senay，2010）检验了“我会”（I will）与“我会……吗”（Will I）（如，“我一周锻炼3次”对比“我会一周锻炼3次吗”）对人们行为的影响。做出陈述（“我会”）比提出问题（“我会……吗”）更有力量，这似乎是个常识。 但研究的结果并非如此。如果人们把意图表述为疑问句，则更有可能实际执行该行为。塞内的理论认为，如果人们问自己一个激发其内在动力的问题，会更容易让他们贯彻始终。 策略127 如果你能让人们问自己一个以“我会”打头的问题，你就有更大可能让他们按照该陈述采取行动。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 2370-2371 | Added on Tuesday, 3 May 2022 21:33:00

拿着重物同时看简历，会让求职者显得更重要。实际上，拿着重物（如一本书）时思考的任何想法，都显得有一种重要感。把想法比喻为“沉重”或“有分量”，这是个物理推论。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 2511-2521 | Added on Friday, 6 May 2022 13:51:38

它的相关术语叫作“具身认知”（embodied cognition），这不光指我们怎样把想法转变成重量，也涉及若干与触觉有关的判断。在心理学研究里，它的正式名称叫“触觉感知”（haptic sensations）。 你兴许会惊讶地发现，这些触觉感知对我们的感觉和判断有着多方面的影响。除了重物效应，人们还会对其他触觉感知有所反应： ·在社交互动中，较之触摸到柔软的物体，如果人们触摸到了粗糙的物体，比如坐在覆盖有粗羊毛坐垫的椅子上，那么，他们会认为这次互动更为艰难。 ·较之触摸到柔软物体，如果人们触摸到了硬物，那么，他们会认为谈判条件更为严苛。 ·较之拿着冰冷的液体，如果人们拿着暖和的杯子（如端着一杯热乎乎的咖啡），那么，他们会认为自己与之互动的人性格更温和。 你可以借助这些触觉感知来让人们做事。如果你希望人们与他人进行更轻松的互动，那么，你可以在会议室里摆放柔软的家具（而非硬质椅子），使用柔软的织物覆盖（而非扎手的粗花呢）。如果你有重要的客户要来办公室，你希望他认为你是个温暖的人，不妨在开始之前给他一杯热咖啡或热茶。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)

心智技巧 激活系统1思考。你希望梅勒妮尽可能多地使用系统1（也就是简单而直觉的）思考。实际上，梅勒妮正在使用系统1思考。你的任务是让她尽可能多地停留在系统1。在提及自己的背景和经历时，你一定要讲述一个连贯一致的故事。 让打印文件易于阅读。因为你想让系统1继续运行，所以，要保证你拿给梅勒妮的所有打印资料，比如书面样本或简历，都使用简单清晰、足够大的字体，方便阅读。不要使用让文本难以阅读的背景颜色。 不要做任何出人意料的事。你可能认为你需要做些不同的事情好让自己脱颖而出，但等到你已经通过了最初的筛选，需要跟梅勒妮进行一对一谈话的时候，不要做任何出人意料的事情，因为那样会让梅勒妮从系统1思考切换到系统2思考。 利用确认偏误。由于确认偏误的存在，梅勒妮会寻找符合自己现有信念的信息。询问足够多的问题，你就能知道她对这份工作有着什么样的心理图式。 然后说一些她本就知道也认同的事情，如：“我知道你想聘用能跟团队其他成员友好相处的人”，或者“在如今这样的经济衰退中，雇用能立刻上手做事的人很要紧”。 提出简单的解决办法，消除模糊状态。人不喜欢模糊状态。不知道该聘用谁会造成模糊状态，进而产生不舒服的感觉。让聘用你成为简单的解决办法。不要引起任何复杂局面（比如突然提出你两个月都不能到岗，因为你答应跟朋友去加勒比海航行）。 让你的名字容易说。记住，如果你的名字很长或很难发音，它会侵蚀你的可信度，把本来容易的事情（比如聘用你）变得困难起来。你或许不可能只是为了想获得聘用而改名字，但你可以试试提供一个简化版：“我的名字叫阿洛伊修斯，但大家都叫我阿洛。” 聚焦于面试的开始和结束部分，并为之做好准备。请记住，人们往往
==========

心智技巧 激活系统1思考。你希望梅勒妮尽可能多地使用系统1（也就是简单而直觉的）思考。实际上，梅勒妮正在使用系统1思考。你的任务是让她尽可能多地停留在系统1。在提及自己的背景和经历时，你一定要讲述一个连贯一致的故事。 让打印文件易于阅读。因为你想让系统1继续运行，所以，要保证你拿给梅勒妮的所有打印资料，比如书面样本或简历，都使用简单清晰、足够大的字体，方便阅读。不要使用让文本难以阅读的背景颜色。 不要做任何出人意料的事。你可能认为你需要做些不同的事情好让自己脱颖而出，但等到你已经通过了最初的筛选，需要跟梅勒妮进行一对一谈话的时候，不要做任何出人意料的事情，因为那样会让梅勒妮从系统1思考切换到系统2思考。 利用确认偏误。由于确认偏误的存在，梅勒妮会寻找符合自己现有信念的信息。询问足够多的问题，你就能知道她对这份工作有着什么样的心理图式。 然后说一些她本就知道也认同的事情，如：“我知道你想聘用能跟团队其他成员友好相处的人”，或者“在如今这样的经济衰退中，雇用能立刻上手做事的人很要紧”。 提出简单的解决办法，消除模糊状态。人不喜欢模糊状态。不知道该聘用谁会造成模糊状态，进而产生不舒服的感觉。让聘用你成为简单的解决办法。不要引起任何复杂局面（比如突然提出你两个月都不能到岗，因为你答应跟朋友去加勒比海航行）。 让你的名字容易说。记住，如果你的名字很长或很难发音，它会侵蚀你的可信度，把本来容易的事情（比如聘用你）变得困难起来。你或许不可能只是为了想获得聘用而改名字，但你可以试试提供一个简化版：“我的名字叫阿洛伊修斯，但大家都叫我阿洛。” 聚焦于面试的开始和结束部分，并为之做好准备。请记住，人们往往会忘记谈话的中间部分，所以一定要在开场白和结束语中说出要点。 本能 利用稀缺性和对损失的恐惧感。如果只有5%的平面设计师有硕士学位，而你又是其中之一，那么一定要提到这一点。拥有硕士学位的人稀缺，故此更有价值。如果你还有其他工作邀约，一定要告诉梅勒妮，让她知道你很抢手。如果你要在某个日期之前给另一家公司答复，也一定要提到这一点。有可能失去你，让你落到竞争对手那里，这个念头有可能会让梅勒妮迅速行动。 归属需求 以员工身份加入一家新公司或一个新组织，就像加入一个部落。我们的许多社会交往和认同感，都通过工作来实现。如果你想要某人聘用你，那么，许多与归属需求相关的策略都是积极的。 尽量多参加现场面试。如果你希望运用归属需求一章里提到的许多设想，也就意味着你希望能面对面地沟通，很多策略是无法在电话联系中使用的。效率最低的是通过信件或电子邮件来做所有的事情。你必须要能直接跟梅勒妮说上话。你至少要跟梅勒妮远程说话，这样，你才能使用说话者和听话者之间大脑同步的策略。 运用纽带。既然你想和梅勒妮建立融洽的关系，不妨试着同步地跟她一起做一些事情，以求建立纽带。举例来说，看看你们俩能否同时因为某件事而大笑起来。尽量从会议一开始就这么做。 做个领导者。如果梅勒妮把你看作领导者，那么你对她会更具说服力。在你们见面时先说话，但要简短——先说话（这是好事）并不等于主导整场谈话（这是坏事）。 注意你的语言。说话自信。不要说太快，也别说太慢。带着激情、活力和热心去交流。 注意你的肢体语言。一定要坐得直，站得挺。不要斜靠在家具上。不要坐得太靠前（暗示过分热切），也不要坐得太靠后（暗示不感兴趣）。在镜子前练习一些对话，确保你的手势跟你传达的信息相符。记得要偶尔直视梅勒妮的眼睛，说话时保持微笑。 使用相似性和吸引力。着装跟梅勒妮、与她同级的人、比她低一级的人类似。你希望梅勒妮相信你能快速融入并适应。弄清你申请的岗位级别穿什么样的衣服，然后穿一套与之相符的漂亮衣着。例如，如果梅勒妮穿的是商务休闲风格，她的下属穿的是休闲牛仔裤，那么，不妨试试两者之间的风格。如果梅勒妮穿商务套装，而她的员工全穿牛仔裤和T恤，你就应该穿商务休闲风格。如果梅勒妮和她的员工全穿套装，那你也应该穿套装。这么做是通过展示自己是群体的一员，建立融洽的关系。如果你曾跟
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 2590-2639 | Added on Sunday, 8 May 2022 10:16:17

心智技巧 激活系统1思考。你希望梅勒妮尽可能多地使用系统1（也就是简单而直觉的）思考。实际上，梅勒妮正在使用系统1思考。你的任务是让她尽可能多地停留在系统1。在提及自己的背景和经历时，你一定要讲述一个连贯一致的故事。 让打印文件易于阅读。因为你想让系统1继续运行，所以，要保证你拿给梅勒妮的所有打印资料，比如书面样本或简历，都使用简单清晰、足够大的字体，方便阅读。不要使用让文本难以阅读的背景颜色。 不要做任何出人意料的事。你可能认为你需要做些不同的事情好让自己脱颖而出，但等到你已经通过了最初的筛选，需要跟梅勒妮进行一对一谈话的时候，不要做任何出人意料的事情，因为那样会让梅勒妮从系统1思考切换到系统2思考。 利用确认偏误。由于确认偏误的存在，梅勒妮会寻找符合自己现有信念的信息。询问足够多的问题，你就能知道她对这份工作有着什么样的心理图式。 然后说一些她本就知道也认同的事情，如：“我知道你想聘用能跟团队其他成员友好相处的人”，或者“在如今这样的经济衰退中，雇用能立刻上手做事的人很要紧”。 提出简单的解决办法，消除模糊状态。人不喜欢模糊状态。不知道该聘用谁会造成模糊状态，进而产生不舒服的感觉。让聘用你成为简单的解决办法。不要引起任何复杂局面（比如突然提出你两个月都不能到岗，因为你答应跟朋友去加勒比海航行）。 让你的名字容易说。记住，如果你的名字很长或很难发音，它会侵蚀你的可信度，把本来容易的事情（比如聘用你）变得困难起来。你或许不可能只是为了想获得聘用而改名字，但你可以试试提供一个简化版：“我的名字叫阿洛伊修斯，但大家都叫我阿洛。” 聚焦于面试的开始和结束部分，并为之做好准备。请记住，人们往往会忘记谈话的中间部分，所以一定要在开场白和结束语中说出要点。 本能 利用稀缺性和对损失的恐惧感。如果只有5%的平面设计师有硕士学位，而你又是其中之一，那么一定要提到这一点。拥有硕士学位的人稀缺，故此更有价值。如果你还有其他工作邀约，一定要告诉梅勒妮，让她知道你很抢手。如果你要在某个日期之前给另一家公司答复，也一定要提到这一点。有可能失去你，让你落到竞争对手那里，这个念头有可能会让梅勒妮迅速行动。 归属需求 以员工身份加入一家新公司或一个新组织，就像加入一个部落。我们的许多社会交往和认同感，都通过工作来实现。如果你想要某人聘用你，那么，许多与归属需求相关的策略都是积极的。 尽量多参加现场面试。如果你希望运用归属需求一章里提到的许多设想，也就意味着你希望能面对面地沟通，很多策略是无法在电话联系中使用的。效率最低的是通过信件或电子邮件来做所有的事情。你必须要能直接跟梅勒妮说上话。你至少要跟梅勒妮远程说话，这样，你才能使用说话者和听话者之间大脑同步的策略。 运用纽带。既然你想和梅勒妮建立融洽的关系，不妨试着同步地跟她一起做一些事情，以求建立纽带。举例来说，看看你们俩能否同时因为某件事而大笑起来。尽量从会议一开始就这么做。 做个领导者。如果梅勒妮把你看作领导者，那么你对她会更具说服力。在你们见面时先说话，但要简短——先说话（这是好事）并不等于主导整场谈话（这是坏事）。 注意你的语言。说话自信。不要说太快，也别说太慢。带着激情、活力和热心去交流。 注意你的肢体语言。一定要坐得直，站得挺。不要斜靠在家具上。不要坐得太靠前（暗示过分热切），也不要坐得太靠后（暗示不感兴趣）。在镜子前练习一些对话，确保你的手势跟你传达的信息相符。记得要偶尔直视梅勒妮的眼睛，说话时保持微笑。 使用相似性和吸引力。着装跟梅勒妮、与她同级的人、比她低一级的人类似。你希望梅勒妮相信你能快速融入并适应。弄清你申请的岗位级别穿什么样的衣服，然后穿一套与之相符的漂亮衣着。例如，如果梅勒妮穿的是商务休闲风格，她的下属穿的是休闲牛仔裤，那么，不妨试试两者之间的风格。如果梅勒妮穿商务套装，而她的员工全穿牛仔裤和T恤，你就应该穿商务休闲风格。如果梅勒妮和她的员工全穿套装，那你也应该穿套装。这么做是通过展示自己是群体的一员，建立融洽的关系。如果你曾跟招聘部门或人力资源部的人共事过，可以问问他们办公室穿什么衣服。他们喜欢求职者这么问。此外，要尽你所能地展现出自己的吸引力。保证你的发型好看，皮肤护理做得很好，衣服熨烫得平平整整，鞋子干净，等等。你或许没有明星般的美貌，但你可以采取手段，尽量展现自己的吸引力。 模仿身体动作和姿势。看看你能否模仿梅勒妮的一些身体姿势和动作。如果梅勒妮把一条腿叠在另一条腿上，你也可以这么做。如果她把手掌摊开放在桌上，你也可以这么做。不要表现得太过明显，但如果你能模仿她的部分动作，将有助于建立融洽的关系。 提到他人的名字。虽然不加选择地过多提及别人的名字，可能叫人觉得很烦，但如果你能提到一些自己效力过，而且梅勒妮也知道的公司的名字，这会对你大有帮助。如果你跟她认识的人共事过，或是为她认识的某个人做过事，你一定要提出来：“在迪士尼做分析师的时候，我的一位同事我想你可能认识，他叫约翰·米尔顿。”这能营造出一种你本就是群体中一员的感觉。 比提及名字更好的做法是：社会认可。找梅勒妮认识的人给你写推荐信。最好在面试之前，让他（她）打电话或写信给梅勒妮。这表明其他人已经把你带进了群体，因此，梅勒妮很可能同样会这么做。
==========

让某人接受一份工作 我一直在为我们部门的一个空缺职位面试候选人。我认为丽莎是最佳人选，并打算向她发出工作邀约。我真心希望她接受这份工作，这样，我就能结束招聘流程，继续做其他工作，而且我还能确定自己的团队里有了一位新来的优秀成员。我该怎么做才能让丽莎接受这份工作呢？ 最适合这种情况的动力是“本能”、“故事的力量”、“归属需求”和“掌控欲”。 故事的力量 接入丽莎的自我人格面具故事。在丽莎接受面试的过程中，你兴许能够弄清她对所从事工作的自我故事是什么样的。借助这些故事，让你的岗位和组织更符合她的故事： ·“我知道，对你来说，重要的是你感觉自己正在创造不同。你能在这份工作中真正感受到这一点。” ·“我知道你是个重视工作和生活平衡的人。这份工作能帮你达成所愿……” ·“根据我们在面试中的交谈，我感觉你是个有雄心的人。这份工作会带给你一展雄心的机会。” 掌控欲 强调新的学习。丽莎会喜欢有机会在工作中学习新技能。要强调出她能学到的所有新东西。 暗示精英团队。我们喜欢感觉自己很特别，是一支精明强干的小团队中的一员。如果你告诉丽莎，“这份工作需要非常特殊的技能和经验。符合要求的人不太多。我们很高兴能找到你，因为你就是为数不多符合要求的人之一。”那么，她有更大可能接受该工作。 提及自主权。我们喜欢感觉自己在工作中享有自主权。如果你告诉丽莎，“在这份工作中，你有机会按自己认为最合适的方式行事。你对工作享有很大的控制权”。那么，她更有可能接受这份工作。 指出工作的挑战。我们喜欢感觉自己正在迎接挑战。如果你对丽莎说，“这不是一份容易的工作。把它做好并非不可能，但极具挑战性。我

让某人接受一份工作 我一直在为我们部门的一个空缺职位面试候选人。我认为丽莎是最佳人选，并打算向她发出工作邀约。我真心希望她接受这份工作，这样，我就能结束招聘流程，继续做其他工作，而且我还能确定自己的团队里有了一位新来的优秀成员。我该怎么做才能让丽莎接受这份工作呢？ 最适合这种情况的动力是“本能”、“故事的力量”、“归属需求”和“掌控欲”。 故事的力量 接入丽莎的自我人格面具故事。在丽莎接受面试的过程中，你兴许能够弄清她对所从事工作的自我故事是什么样的。借助这些故事，让你的岗位和组织更符合她的故事： ·“我知道，对你来说，重要的是你感觉自己正在创造不同。你能在这份工作中真正感受到这一点。” ·“我知道你是个重视工作和生活平衡的人。这份工作能帮你达成所愿……” ·“根据我们在面试中的交谈，我感觉你是个有雄心的人。这份工作会带给你一展雄心的机会。” 掌控欲 强调新的学习。丽莎会喜欢有机会在工作中学习新技能。要强调出她能学到的所有新东西。 暗示精英团队。我们喜欢感觉自己很特别，是一支精明强干的小团队中的一员。如果你告诉丽莎，“这份工作需要非常特殊的技能和经验。符合要求的人不太多。我们很高兴能找到你，因为你就是为数不多符合要求的人之一。”那么，她有更大可能接受该工作。 提及自主权。我们喜欢感觉自己在工作中享有自主权。如果你告诉丽莎，“在这份工作中，你有机会按自己认为最合适的方式行事。你对工作享有很大的控制权”。那么，她更有可能接受这份工作。 指出工作的挑战。我们喜欢感觉自己正在迎接挑战。如果你对丽莎说，“这不是一份容易的工作。把它做好并非不可能，但极具挑战性。我们相信你拥有成功所需的技能和知识。”那么，她会对这份工作更感兴趣。 不要显得太容易。如果丽莎觉得自己必须努力争取才能得到那份工作，她会更想要它。要确保求职的过程中，她必须克服一些障碍。要她接受两轮以上面试，并要求她提交简历和工作资历集。索要推荐信，并加以核实。采取这些步骤，会让丽莎有更大可能接受这份工作。 本能 激活稀缺和害怕失去的念头。一定要让丽莎知道你在面试其他求职者，以及你必须在某个即将到来的日期前做出最后决定。由于担忧花太长时间做决定可能失去这份工作，她会更快地接受这份工作。 在对话中尽量使用“你”而非“我们”。比如，“你会喜欢在XYZ公司工作的。你会发现……” 归属需求 至少在部分程度上，丽莎在决定是否加入你的群体（也就是你的公司或组织）。如果你让她觉得自己是你群体的一员，她很可能答应接受这份工作。 如果你不确定丽莎是否接受你的邀约，试着当面对她发出邀请。如果这做不到，至少要打电话告诉丽莎。如果你通过邮件或电子邮件进行联系，那么很多策略都无法使用。面对面沟通，你能运用的策略最多。 运用纽带。既然你想和丽莎建立融洽的关系，不妨试着跟她一起同步做一些事情，以求建立纽带。举例来说，看看你们俩能否同时因为某件事而大笑起来。尽量从会议一开始就这么做。 注意你的语言。说话自信。不要说太快，也别说太慢。带着激情、活力和热心去交流。 模仿身体动作和姿势。看看你能否在面试过程中模仿丽莎的一些身体姿势和动作，这将有助于建立融洽的关系。

让别人接受你为供应商 我要去见一位潜在客户。我希望客户能和我们签订供应合同，采用我们的技术咨询服务。我安排了跟该公司副总裁斯科特的会议，谈一谈为什么他应该考虑在下一代技术项目中把我们作为供应商。 最适合这种情况的动力跟获得聘用的一样，分别是“心智技巧”、“本能”和“归属需求”。 心智技巧 激活系统1思考。你希望斯科特尽可能多地使用系统1（也就是简单而直觉的）思考。在提到你的公司、你提供的服务、你效力过的客户时，要使用清晰、简单、连贯的信息。简单最好。 让资料易于阅读。因为你想让系统1继续运行，所以，要保证你拿给斯科特的所有打印资料，比如提案或报价，都使用简单清晰、足够大的字体，方便阅读。不要使用让文本难以阅读的背景颜色。 提出简单的解决办法，消除模糊状态。人不喜欢模糊状态。不知道采用哪家的服务，会造成模糊状态，进而产生不舒服的感觉。让采用你方服务，成为简单的解决办法。不要引起任何复杂局面（比如说，必须向法务部提供一份冗长、让人糊涂的合同）。 让你的名字容易说。记住，如果你的名字很长或很难发音，它会侵蚀你的可信度，把本来容易的事情（比如跟你签合同）变得困难起来。如果你公司的名字又长又复杂，提供缩短版或缩略词。 聚焦于会议的开始和结束部分。请记住，人们往往会忘记谈话的中间部分，所以一定要在开场白和结束语中说出要点。 在提到钱之前建立融洽的关系。在谈钱之前，一定要和斯科特建立起融洽的关系。谈钱会让人变得独立，降低合作意愿。 使用锚点鼓励斯科特购买更多的产品和服务。提供不超过三档的服务或产品组合。先介绍价格最贵的一档，以便锚定高价。 本能 利用稀缺性和对损失的恐惧感。让斯科特知道你很忙，你希望跟他合作，如果他能快些拿定主意，你兴许能把他排上日程表。由于你太忙，斯科特有可能失去跟你和你的公司合作的机会，这种想法会让你显得更具吸

说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 2692-2710 | Added on Sunday, 8 May 2022 12:12:15

归属需求 使用互惠。给斯科特一些东西，以让他对你产生亏欠感。给他一次免费试用的机会，或是做能让他感觉你给了他一件重要东西、帮了他一个忙的任何事情。 尽量亲自见面。光靠打电话，你无法使用归属需求下的许多策略。效果最差的沟通方式是邮件或电子邮件。你最好是直接跟斯科特交谈。你至少要远程跟他通话，以实现你们大脑之间的同步。 运用纽带。既然你想和斯科特建立融洽的关系，不妨试着跟他一起同步做一些事情，以求建立纽带。举例来说，看看你们俩能否同时因为某件事而大笑起来。尽量从会议一开始就这么做。 做个领导者。如果斯科特把你看作领导者，你对他会更具说服力。在你们见面时先说话，但要简短——先说话（这是好事）并不等于主导整场谈话（这是坏事）。 注意你的语言。说话自信。不要说太快，也别说太慢。带着激情、活力和热心去交流。 注意你的肢体语言。一定要坐得直，站得挺。不要斜靠在家具上。不要坐得太靠前（暗示过分热切），也不要坐得太靠后（暗示不感兴趣）。在镜子前练习一些对话，确保你的手势跟你传达的信息相符。记得要偶尔直视斯科特的眼睛，说话时保持微笑。 使用相似性和吸引力。着装风格跟斯科特相似。要尽你所能地展现出自己的吸引力。保证你的发型好看、皮肤护理做得很好，衣服熨烫得平平整整，鞋子干净，等等。 模仿身体动作和姿势。看看你能否模仿斯科特一些身体姿势和动作，这将有助于建立融洽的关系。 提到他人的名字。虽然不加选择地过多提及别人的名字，可能叫人觉得很烦，但如果你能提到一些自己效力过，而且斯科特也知道的公司的名字，这会对你大有帮助。 从相识的人那里获得推荐或引荐。比提及名字更好的做法是社会认可。找斯科特认识的人（不管是否来自他的公司）给你引荐。最好在你们见面之前，让他（她）打电话或写信给斯科特。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 2805-2815 | Added on Sunday, 8 May 2022 12:21:28

心智技巧 先跟伊丽莎白聊一些她本就知道也认同的事情。你会希望回避任何确认偏误（也就是我们只注意那些与自己本就相信的事情吻合的东西），不让她转入戒备、自我辩解的心态。一开始先跟她说些她知道而且认同的事情。我没法告诉你这些事具体是什么，因为我不像你那么了解她。如果你知道她认为健康很重要而且也认同这一点，那就从这里开始。如果她知道自己最近的生活方式有待改进，从这类开始也不错。总之，从她本就知道也认同的事情开始，你才能接下去讨论她有可能不认同的事情。 等你从伊丽莎白知道也认同的事情开始聊得越来越深入，你就可以引入认知失调了。你可以从一些健康方面的统计数据着手：跟运动较多的同龄人比起来，中年以上不运动的女性（每星期运动不到一小时）死于心血管疾病的风险是前者的两倍。伊丽莎白想要健康长寿，但现在她必须面对的事实是：她所处的群体有着两倍高的风险。这会造成认知失调，让她感到不舒服。 提供一种简单的解决办法来消除认知失调。在认知失调的关头你提供一种答案或解决办法，消除失调，她会更有可能采取行动。例如，你可以说，“从现在开始，我们每星期一起去3次健身房怎么样？”
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 2800-2805 | Added on Sunday, 8 May 2022 12:22:04

习惯 帮助伊丽莎白建立跟旧习惯挂钩的新习惯。由于我们每天做的很多事情都是习惯性的，你可以观察伊丽莎白现有的习惯，并将更健康的新习惯跟现有的习惯挂钩，帮助她吃得更健康，做更多的锻炼。不要光注意她不健康的习惯。相反，要观察那些中立的习惯（去商店，喂狗），并将健康的新习惯与之挂钩。例如，每当她要喂狗时，她就可以准备出门散步，等狗吃完东西，她们可以一起散步20分钟；每当她准备去杂货店买东西时，她就可以列出一张健康食品的清单，加入自己的购物单。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 2816-2827 | Added on Sunday, 8 May 2022 12:25:30

本能 激发对损失的恐惧，激励伊丽莎白采取行动。如果她害怕失去自己的健康、寿命或行动力，你可以用这些想法来促使她采取行动。 提出数量有限的选择。不要告诉她10件可以有所改变的事情，这会把她累垮。太多的选择会让她根本不做选择。相反，给她少量的建议（不要超过3或4条），让她知道有哪些地方可以采取不同做法。 胡萝卜加大棒。对你想鼓励的行为给予奖励。想一想有哪些事情可以充当你妈妈的激励因素，并能在她做了某件有助于健康生活方式的事情之后加以应用。例如，假设能和你多待在一起，对她来说是一种奖励。如果她和你一起去了健身房，锻炼完之后立刻带她去喝杯咖啡，聊聊天。 归属需求 使用社会认可。如果你知道伊丽莎白的某个朋友或她羡慕的名人过着健康的生活方式，多向她提起这些人。 把她和其他活跃的人联系起来。如果她认为自己是群体的一员，她更有可能继续参加活动。 用名词代替动词，让她觉得自己是健康生活方式群体的一分子。例如，试着说“看到你成了个游泳健将，这真是太棒了”，而不是“看到你游泳真是太棒了”。
==========
说服的艺术——促使人行动的七种心理动力【塑造美好人际关系和强大个人影响的实用指南，著名行为心理学家30年研究成果。适用团队、亲子、家庭、社群等各种场景。】 (苏珊·威辛克)
- Your Highlight at location 2827-2833 | Added on Sunday, 8 May 2022 12:25:50

故事的力量 分享其他拥有健康生活方式的人的故事。当伊丽莎白听到其他人正在模仿你期待她做到的行为，她兴许会为自己创造一个新的故事。 如果她的自我人格面具跟健康的生活方式相契合，那就让她做一件与这一自我形象匹配的事情：“我知道你喜欢保持活跃。我想，兴许你乐意星期天跟我一起去骑自行车。” 如果她目前的自我人格面具与健康的生活方式不一致，让她做一些与当前生活方式不一致的非常小的事情，例如，“我们今天一起去散会儿步吧。”一旦她采取了与当前自我人格面具不一致的行动，她会更容易着手建立与新活动相符合的新人格面具。

Lions Don't Need to Roar: Using the Leadership Power of Personal Presence to Stand Out, Fit in and Move Ahead (Benton, D. A.)
- Your Highlight on page 33 | location 479-483 | Added on Tuesday, 10 May 2022 20:40:15

Chiefs control where they look, and they don’t avoid eye contact. The higher up the ladder someone goes, the longer he will maintain eye contact. When he encounters people of lesser rank, they invariably break eye contact before he does. I’ve walked down a hallway with many a Ms. or Mr. Big and watched one person after another avert his or her eyes. Clearly, if you want to stand out when you meet a chief (or anyone else you hope to impress), you can’t nervously lower your gaze as other people do. Maintain eye contact.
==========

- Your Highlight on page 33 | location 487-489 | Added on Tuesday, 10 May 2022 20:45:41

Effective eye contact and communication helps you: look more alert, attentive and alive; concentrate on what’s being said to you; appear unafraid; convey to others that they are important and that you are listening to them; look confident.

Here are five options for communicating effectively with your eyes: Look at someone’s entire face, rather than only boring into his eyes. Watch people’s lips while they’re speaking; “reading” lips helps you hear what they are saying. Focus first on one of the speaker’s eyes and then on the other eye. It can make you, as the listener, look particularly attentive.

Practice maintaining eye contact until you can hold someone’s gaze a second longer than formality requires. That extra second gives you an aura of confidence and says, “I can take the heat.”

Lions Don't Need to Roar: Using the Leadership Power of Personal Presence to Stand Out, Fit in and Move Ahead (Benton, D. A.)

==========
Lions Don't Need to Roar: Using the Leadership Power of Personal Presence to Stand Out, Fit in and Move Ahead (Benton, D. A.)
- Your Highlight on page 44 | location 616-625 | Added on Tuesday, 10 May 2022 21:58:27

Consider this scenario: A boss has gathered his key people together so that he can “pass the baton of power” to Joe, who will be running the business in his absence. Standing at the head of a long boardroom table with all eyes upon him, the boss begins, “As you know, I’m leaving for a six-month sabbatical. While I’m gone, Joe is going to be at the helm.” The boss points toward Joe, who is seated to his left, and continues. “Look to Joe for help with any questions or problems. He’ll be in charge.” Now, consider this alternative: In the same situation, the same boss makes the same announcement. Only this time, when he says, “While I’m gone, Joe is going to be at the helm,” he takes two steps to his left, places his hand firmly on Joe’s shoulder, and continues. “Look to Joe for help with any questions or problems. He’ll be in charge.” Did the second scenario inspire more confidence in Joe than the first? Absolutely. Someone who witnessed the boss’s hand on Joe’s shoulder would be apt to feel more comfortable following Joe’s lead than someone who did not. A simple touch made the difference. It usually does—if it’s the right touch at the right moment. Had the boss ruffled Joe’s hair or patted his cheek as he would a child’s, his touch would have been inappropriate—and ineffective.

“竞争这么激烈，生意没法做

语言的魔力 书评1 (douban)
- Your Highlight at location 41-44 | Added on Friday, 13 May 2022 14:40:24

“你认为竞争激烈，生意就没法做，是吗？”   　　当事人听到这句话，他的潜意识就会收到一个信息：这只是他个人的一个想法，并不是事实。这就为后面破除这一信念打下了一个基础。
==========
语言的魔力 书评1 (douban)
- Your Highlight at location 49-51 | Added on Friday, 13 May 2022 14:40:31

==========
语言的魔力 书评1 (douban)
- Your Highlight at location 57-64 | Added on Friday, 13 May 2022 14:43:16

要一下子动摇一个限制性信念，可能不太容易做到，如果动摇一条桌子脚，那就容易多了，拨掉了桌子脚，整张桌子就会倒下来。   　　这里所用的语言模式是，通过发问，找出支持这一限制性信念的证据，然后一一动摇：   　　“是什么让你觉得生意没法做呢？”   　　通过这一问话，当事人一定会向你展示很多的证据，当你找到了他桌子脚，你就可以用其他方法去破解。
==========
语言的魔力 书评1 (douban)

==========
语言的魔力 书评1 (douban)
- Your Highlight at location 70-72 | Added on Friday, 13 May 2022 14:43:37

“在竞争这么激烈的市场中，什么人才能做好生意呢？”   　　“在竞争这么激烈的市场中，用什么办法才能做好生意呢？”
==========
语言的魔力 书评1 (douban)
- Your Highlight at location 76-80 | Added on Friday, 13 May 2022 14:44:07

做任何事情都需要能力，那怕是形成一个限制性信念也不例外！当一个人知道自己很有能力时，就没有什么东西可以限制他了。所以，在这一模式里，教练只需要把限制性信念后面所隐藏的那份能力告诉当事人就足够了：   　　“你能意识到这一点，证明你对市场有相当敏锐的观察力，这对一个企业家来说，是非常关键的。”
==========
语言的魔力 书评1 (douban)
- Your Highlight at location 83-90 | Added on Friday, 13 May 2022 14:44:43

每一个行为的背后，都有有其正面动机”，这是NLP的前提假设之一。一个人会抱著一个限制性的信念不放，一定是这一信念会给当事人带来好处，所以，要改变一个限制性的信念，必须要保留这一信念带给他的好处。   　　在这一模式里，教练需要帮助当事人找出限制性信念后面的意义和正面动机：   　　“当你这样想的时候，会带给你什么？”   　　“当你这样想的时候，会给你的生意带来什么好处？
==========
语言的魔力 书评1 (douban)
- Your Highlight at location 93-101 | Added on Friday, 13 May 2022 14:44:56

凡事有三个以上的解决办法”，当找出了当事人所要的好处后，教练就可以带他去看得到这个好处的其他方法：   　　“要得到这一点，还有其他方法吗？”   　　“还有呢？”   　　“除了上面所说的之外，还有吗？”   　　“假如有的话，会是什么呢？”   　　“在上面所说的这些方法中，那一个是最关键的？”
==========
语言的魔力 书评1 (douban)
- Your Highlight at location 111-122 | Added on Friday, 13 May 2022 14:45:45

环境换框模式：   　　同样的一件东西或一个情况，在不同的环境中包含的价值会有所不同。找出有利的环境，便能改变这件东西或这个情况的价值，因而改变有关的信念。   　　“竞争这么激烈，生意没法做。”，教练可以把这一信念的推演到其他环境中，比如可以说，当你与人下棋时，你的对手实力与你相差很大，完全不是你的对手，一点竞争都没有，你会觉得这好玩吗？   　　再比如，一位朋友老抱怨他的太太很固执，夫妻关系搞得很糟。他来问我怎么办，我问问他：“当你太太的老板对你太太有非份的企图时，你是希望她固执呢还是不固执?”其实固执本身没有好坏之分，好坏决定于在什么环境中运用而已。他以后便再也不为太太的固执而发脾气了。   　　这就是环境换框模式，教练要做的是带领当事人换个环境来看看他所持有的信念，让他自己有所动摇。
==========
语言的魔力 书评1 (douban)
- Your Highlight at location 104-109 | Added on Friday, 13 May 2022 14:45:52

、 意义换框模式：   　　所有的事本身是没有意义的，所有的意义都是人加上去的。既然是人加上去的意义，则一件事情可以有其他的意义，也可以有更多的意义，可以有不好的意义，也可以有好的意义。   　　“竞争激烈”可以有“生意没法做”的意义，同时也可以有“竞争激烈才可以锻炼一个企业家的素质”的意义，当然，还有更多的意义。
==========

2、 环境换框模式：   　　同样的一件东西或一个情况，在不同的环境中包含的价值会有所不同。找出有利的环境，便能改变这件东西或这个情况的价值，因而改变有关的信念。   　　“竞争这么激烈，生意没法做。”，教练可以把这一信念的推演到其他环境中，比如可以说，当你与人下棋时，你的对手实力与你相差很大，完全不是你的对手，一点竞争都没有，你会觉得这好玩吗？   　　再比如，一位朋友老抱怨他的太太很固执，夫妻关系搞得很糟。他来问我怎么办，我问问他：“当你太太的老板对你太太有非份的企图时，你是希望她固执呢还是不固执?”其实固执本身没有好坏之分，好坏决定于在什么环境中运用而已。他以后便再也不为太太的固执而发脾气了。   　　这就是环境换框模式，教练要做的是带领当事人换个环境来看看他所持有的信念，让他自己有所动摇。

TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 61-64 | Added on Sunday, 22 May 2022 15:18:00

Indeed, even if there were a successful formula at one moment in time, it wouldn’t stay successful for long. That’s because a key part of the appeal of a great talk is its freshness. We’re humans. We don’t like same old, same old. If your talk feels too similar to a talk someone has already heard, it is bound to have less impact. The last thing we want is for everyone to sound the same or for anyone to sound as though he’s faking it.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 239-243 | Added on Sunday, 22 May 2022 15:35:08

Your goal is not to be Winston Churchill or Nelson Mandela. It’s to be you. If you’re a scientist, be a scientist; don’t try to be an activist. If you’re an artist, be an artist; don’t try to be an academic. If you’re just an ordinary person, don’t try to fake some big intellectual style; just be you. You don’t have to raise a crowd to its feet with a thunderous oration. Conversational sharing can work just as well. In fact, for most audiences, it’s a lot better. If you know how to talk to a group of friends over dinner, then you know enough to speak publicly.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)

Your number-one mission as a speaker is to take something that matters deeply to you and to rebuild it inside the minds of your listeners.

TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 383-387 | Added on Sunday, 22 May 2022 16:00:10

Speaker Tierney Thys puts it this way: Like all good movies or books, a great talk is transporting. We love to go on adventures, travel someplace new with an informed, if not quirky, guide who can introduce us to things we never knew existed, incite us to crawl out windows into strange worlds, outfit us with new lenses to see the ordinary in an extraordinary way . . . enrapture us and engage multiple parts of our brains simultaneously. So I often try to fashion my talks around embarking on a journey.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 382-387 | Added on Sunday, 22 May 2022 16:00:16

There’s one other beautiful metaphor for a great talk. It is a journey that speaker and audience take together. Speaker Tierney Thys puts it this way: Like all good movies or books, a great talk is transporting. We love to go on adventures, travel someplace new with an informed, if not quirky, guide who can introduce us to things we never knew existed, incite us to crawl out windows into strange worlds, outfit us with new lenses to see the ordinary in an extraordinary way . . . enrapture us and engage multiple parts of our brains simultaneously. So I often try to fashion my talks around embarking on a journey.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 387-391 | Added on Sunday, 22 May 2022 16:02:48

What’s powerful about this metaphor is that it makes clear why the speaker, like any tour guide, must begin where the audience is. And why they must ensure no impossible leaps or inexplicable shifts in direction. Whether the journey is one of exploration, explanation, or persuasion, the net result is to have brought the audience to a beautiful new place. And that too is a gift. Whichever metaphor you use, focusing on what you will give to your audience is the perfect foundation for preparing your talk.

TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 442-447 | Added on Sunday, 22 May 2022 17:54:07

An organization is fascinating to those who work for it—and deeply boring to almost everyone else. Sorry, but it’s true. Any talk framed around the exceptional history of your company or NGO or lab and the complex-but-oh-so-impressive way it is structured, and the fabulously photogenic quality of the astonishingly talented team working with you, and how much success your products are having, is going to leave your audience snoozing at the starting line. It may be interesting to you and your team. But, alas, we don’t work there. Everything changes, though, when you focus on the nature of the work that you’re doing, and the power of the ideas that infuse it, not on the org itself or its products.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 450-454 | Added on Sunday, 22 May 2022 17:54:30

“Back in 2005, we set up a new department in Dallas in this office building [slide of glass tower here], and its goal was to investigate how we could slash our energy costs, so I allocated Vice President Hank Boreham to the task . . .” Yawn. Compare that statement to this one: “Back in 2005 we discovered something surprising. It turns out that it’s possible for an average office to slash its energy costs by 60 percent without any noticeable loss of productivity. Let me share with you how . . .” One mode retains interest. One kills it. One mode is a gift. The other is lazily self-serving.
==========

Your throughline doesn’t have to be as ambitious as those above. But it still should have some kind of intriguing angle. you, the speaker, want the audience to come with you, you probably need to give them a hint of where you’re going. And then you need to be sure that each step of the journey helps get you there. In this journey metaphor, the throughline traces the path that the journey takes. It ensures that there are no impossible leaps, and that by the end of the talk, the speaker
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 556-559 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 16:41:18

But if you, the speaker, want the audience to come with you, you probably need to give them a hint of where you’re going. And then you need to be sure that each step of the journey helps get you there. In this journey metaphor, the throughline traces the path that the journey takes. It ensures that there are no impossible leaps, and that by the end of the talk, the speaker and audience have arrived together at a satisfying destination.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)

TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 601-605 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 16:48:16

I found my ego really trapping me. If my TED Talk goes viral, I need people to know what a great pianist I am! That I can also paint! That I write fantastic lyrics! That I have all these OTHER talents! THIS IS MY CHANCE! But, no. The only way the talk can truly soar is if you take your ego out of it and let yourself be a delivery vehicle for the ideas themselves. I remember going to dinner with TED regular Nicholas Negroponte and asked if he had any advice for my talk. He said something that my Buddhist-leaning mentor has been saying for years: leave space and SAY LESS.

TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 612-626 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 16:51:34

Let’s say I’ve been asked to speak for just 2 minutes to introduce who I am. Here’s version 1: Although I’m British, I was born in Pakistan—my father was a missionary eye surgeon—and my early years were spent there and in India and Afghanistan. At age thirteen, I was sent to boarding school in England, and after that I went to Oxford University for a degree in Philosophy, Politics, and Economics. I started work as a local newspaper journalist in Wales, then moved to a pirate radio station in the Seychelles Islands for a couple of years to write and read a world news service. Back in the UK in the mid-1980s, I fell in love with computers and started a series of magazines devoted to them. It was a great time to be launching specialist magazines, and my company doubled in size every year for seven years. I sold it, moved to the US, and tried again. By the year 2000 my business had grown to 2,000 employees and 150 magazines and websites. But the tech bubble was about to burst, and when it did, it nearly destroyed the company. Besides, who needs magazines when you have the Internet? I left at the end of 2001. Happily, I had put some money into a nonprofit foundation that I was able to use to buy TED, which, back then, was an annual conference in California. That’s been my full-time passion ever since. And here’s version 2: I want you to come with me to a student’s room at Oxford University in 1977. You open the door, and at first it seems like there’s nobody there. But wait. Over in the corner, there’s a boy lying on the floor, face up, staring at the ceiling. He’s been like that for more than 90 minutes. That’s me. Twenty-year-old me. I am thinking. Hard. I am
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 626-636 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 16:51:41

trying . . . please don’t laugh . . . I am trying to solve the problem of free will. That deep mystery that has stumped the world’s philosophers for at least two millennia? Yup, I’m taking it on. Anyone looking objectively at the scene would have concluded that this boy was some weird combination of arrogant, deluded, or perhaps just socially awkward and lonely, preferring the company of ideas to people. But my own narrative? I’m a dreamer. I’ve always been obsessed by the power of ideas. And I’m pretty sure it’s that inward focus that helped me survive growing up in boarding schools in India and England, away from my missionary parents, and that gave me the confidence to try to build a media company. Certainly it was the dreamer in me that fell in love so deeply with TED. Most recently I’ve been dreaming about the revolution in public speaking, and what it could lead to . . . So which version tells you more about me? The first one certainly has far more facts. It’s a decent summary of big parts of my life. A 2-minute resume. The second one focuses on just a single moment of my life. And yet, when I try this experiment on people, they say they find the second far more interesting, and also far more revealing.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 642-644 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 16:53:53

So a throughline requires you first to identify an idea that can be properly unpacked in the time you have available. You should then build a structure so that every element in your talk is somehow linked to this idea.

TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 663-663 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 17:42:01

TACKLING TOUGH TOPICS
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 664-669 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 17:42:29

Your throughline needs handling with special care if you have to speak on a heavy subject. The horror of a refugee crisis. The diabetes explosion. Gender-related violence in South America. Many speakers on these topics view their job as to highlight a cause that needs to be more widely known. The structure of these talks is typically to lay out a series of facts that illustrate how awful a situation is and why something must be done to fix it. And indeed there are times when that is the perfect way to frame a talk . . . provided you’re confident that your listeners are ready and willing to be made to feel uncomfortable. The trouble is that if an audience sits through too many talks like
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 669-676 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 17:42:39

this, it will get emotionally exhausted and will start to switch off. Compassion fatigue sets in. If that happens before your talk is done, you’ll have no impact. How can you route around that? The first step is to think of your talk not as being about an issue, but about an idea. My former colleague June Cohen framed the difference this way: An issue-based talk leads with morality. An idea-based talk leads with curiosity. An issue exposes a problem. An idea proposes a solution. An issue says, “Isn’t this terrible?” An idea says, “Isn’t this interesting?” It’s much easier to pull in an audience by framing the talk as an attempt to solve an intriguing riddle rather than as a plea for them to care. The first feels like a gift being offered. The second feels like an ask.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 690-701 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 17:48:02

Best-selling author Elizabeth Gilbert also believes in planning a talk for an audience of one. She offered me this advice: “Choose a human being—an actual human being in your life—and prepare your talk as if you will be delivering it to that one person only. Choose someone who is not in your field, but who is generally an intelligent, curious, engaged, worldly person—and someone whom you really like. This will bring a warmth of spirit and heart to your talk. Most of all, be sure you are actually speaking to one person, and not to a demographic (‘My speech is for people in the software field who are between the ages of twenty-two and thirty-eight.’), because a demographic is not a human being, and if you speak to a demographic, you will not sound like you are speaking to a human being. You don’t have to go to their house and practice your talk on them for six months; they don’t even need to know that you’re doing this. Just choose your one ideal listener, and then do your best to create a talk that would blow their mind, or move them, or fascinate them, or delight them.” But most important of all, says Gilbert, is to pick a topic that lives deep within you. “Talk about what you know. Talk about what you know and love with all your heart. I want to hear about the subject that is most important to your life—not some random subject that you think will be a novelty. Bring me your well-worn passion of decades, not some fresh, radical gimmick, and trust me—I will be captivated.”
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 713-713 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 17:49:46

Knowledge can’t be pushed into a brain. It has to be pulled in.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 713-715 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 17:50:13

Before you can build an idea in someone else’s mind, you need their permission. People are naturally cautious about opening up their minds—the most precious thing they own—to complete strangers. You need to find a way to overcome that caution. And the way you do that is to make visible the human being cowering inside you.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 716-719 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 17:51:34

Hearing a talk is a completely different thing from reading an essay. It’s not just the words. Not at all. It’s the person delivering the words. To make an impact, there has to be a human connection. You can give the most brilliant talk, with crystal-clear explanations and laser-sharp logic, but if you don’t first connect with the audience, it just won’t land. Even if the content is, at some level, understood, it won’t be activated but simply filed away in some soon-to-be-forgotten mental archive.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 747-749 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 18:00:08

Scientists have shown that just the act of two people staring at each other will trigger mirror neuron activity that literally adopts the emotional state of the other person. If I’m beaming, I will make you smile inside. Just a bit. But a meaningful bit. If I’m nervous, you’ll feel a little anxious too. We look at each other, and our minds sync.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 763-773 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 18:07:29

Brené Brown gave a wonderful talk on vulnerability at TEDxHouston, and she began it appropriately. A couple years ago, an event planner called me because I was going to do a speaking event. And she said, “I’m really struggling with how to write about you on the little flyer.” And I thought, “Well, what’s the struggle?” And she said, “Well, I saw you speak, and I’m going to call you a researcher, I think, but I’m afraid if I call you a researcher, no one will come, because they’ll think you’re boring and irrelevant.” You love her already. By the same logic, if you’re feeling nervous, it can actually work in your favor. Audiences sense it instantly and—far from despising you as you may fear, the opposite happens—they begin rooting for you. We often encourage speakers who look like they may struggle with nerves to simply be ready, if necessary, to acknowledge it. If you feel yourself choking up, then pause . . . pick up a bottle of water, take a sip, and just say what you’re feeling. “Hang in there a moment . . . As you can see, I’m feeling a little nervous here. Normal service will be restored soon.” Likely as not, you’ll get a warm round of applause, and a crowd dying for you to succeed.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 761-761 | Added on Tuesday, 24 May 2022 18:07:34

A story is only ready to share when the presenter’s healing and growth is not dependent on the audience’s response to it.”

part of the evolutionary purpose of laughter is to create social bonding. When you laugh with someone, you both feel you’re on the same side. It’s a fantastic tool for building a connection.

TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)

Be yourself. The worst talks are the ones where someone is trying to be someone they aren’t. If you are generally goofy, then be goofy. If you are emotional, then be emotional. The one exception to that is if you are arrogant and self-centered. Then you should definitely pretend to be someone else.

TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 903-906 | Added on Wednesday, 25 May 2022 15:08:29

When you can pull together humor, self-deprecation, and insight into a single story, you have yourself a winning start. The stories that can generate the best connection are stories about you personally or about people close to you. Tales of failure, awkwardness, misfortune, danger, or disaster, told authentically, are often the moment when listeners shift from plain vanilla interest to deep engagement. They have started to share some of your emotions. They have started to care about you. They have started to like you.

This cool new concept of the experience simulator has suddenly taken you to a place you didn’t expect. A baffling place. The facts you’re presented with make no sense. You’re experiencing a knowledge gap and your mind is craving that it be filled.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 1099-1102 | Added on Wednesday, 25 May 2022 20:49:08

This cool new concept of the experience simulator has suddenly taken you to a place you didn’t expect. A baffling place. The facts you’re presented with make no sense. You’re experiencing a knowledge gap and your mind is craving that it be filled. So Gilbert proceeds to fill it, by offering another new concept.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 1127-1129 | Added on Wednesday, 25 May 2022 20:52:54

Step 1. He started right where we were. Both literally, “When you have 21 minutes to speak . . . ,” and conceptually, without daunting assumptions about our knowledge of psychology or neuroscience. Step 2. He lit a fire called curiosity. Curiosity is what makes
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 1129-1139 | Added on Wednesday, 25 May 2022 20:53:01

people ask why? and how? It’s the feeling that something doesn’t quite make sense. That there’s a knowledge gap that has to be closed. This happened right at the start and then was dialed up dramatically with his unexpected data about paraplegics and lottery winners. Step 3. He brought in concepts one by one. You can’t understand the main concept without first being introduced to the pieces on which it depends, in this case prefrontal cortex, experience simulator, and impact bias. Step 4. He used metaphors. It took metaphors like the flight simulator and the psychological immune system to make clear what he was talking about. For an explanation to be satisfying it has to take puzzling facts and build a connection from them to someone’s existing mental model of the world. Metaphors and analogies are the key tools needed to do this. They help shape the explanation until finally it snaps into place with a satisfying aha! Step 5. He used examples. Little stories, like that of Pete Best, help lock the explanation into place. This is like saying to the brain: You think you understand this idea? Then apply it to these facts. If it fits, you’ve got this figured out.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 1193-1197 | Added on Wednesday, 25 May 2022 21:01:46

What this means is that some of the most important elements in a talk are the little phrases that give clues to the talk’s overall structure: “Although . . .” “One recent example . . .” “On the other hand . . .” “Let’s build on that . . .” “Playing devil’s advocate for a moment . . .” “I must just tell you two stories that amplify this finding.” “As an aside . . .” “At this point you may object that . . .” “So, in summary . . .”

how I think of you. There’s about a trillion

TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 1371-1374 | Added on Thursday, 26 May 2022 15:40:31

The power of this structure is that it taps deep into our love of stories. The whole talk feels like a story—better yet, a mystery story. Curiosity builds to more curiosity through to a satisfying conclusion. But at the same time, there’s a powerful logic underlying it. If each of these alternatives is false, and there’s only one other viable alternative, then that alternative must be true. Case solved!
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 1368-1374 | Added on Thursday, 26 May 2022 15:41:05

Economist Emily Oster wanted to persuade us that the tools of economics could allow us to think differently about HIV/AIDS, but instead of just presenting an economic argument, she became a detective. She presented a slide titled FOUR THINGS WE KNOW. Taking each one in turn, she presented some surprising pieces of evidence and effectively demolished them, one by one, opening the door for her to present an alternative theory. The power of this structure is that it taps deep into our love of stories. The whole talk feels like a story—better yet, a mystery story. Curiosity builds to more curiosity through to a satisfying conclusion. But at the same time, there’s a powerful logic underlying it. If each of these alternatives is false, and there’s only one other viable alternative, then that alternative must be true. Case solved!
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 1377-1379 | Added on Thursday, 26 May 2022 15:44:44

Most people are capable of being convinced by logic, but they aren’t always energized by it. And without being energized, they may quickly forget the argument and move on. So the language of reason may have to be bolstered by other tools that make the conclusions not just valid, but meaningful, exciting, desirable.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 1381-1388 | Added on Thursday, 26 May 2022 15:47:42

Inject some humor early on. This communicates a useful message: I’m going to pull you through some demanding thinking . . . but it’s going to be fun. We’ll sweat together and laugh together. Add an anecdote. Maybe one that reveals how you got engaged in this issue. It humanizes you. If people know why you’re passionate about the issue, they’re more likely to listen to your logic. Offer vivid examples. If I wanted to persuade you that external reality is nothing like you believe it to be, I might first show a slide of a dramatic optical illusion. Just because something looks a certain way, doesn’t make it so. Recruit third-party validation. “My colleagues at Harvard and I have spent ten years looking at the data, and we’ve unanimously
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 1388-1398 | Added on Thursday, 26 May 2022 15:47:46

concluded it has to be seen this way.” Or, “And that’s why it’s not just me arguing this; every mother of a two-year-old boy knows this to be true.” Statements like these need careful handling as neither is a valid argument in itself, but, depending on the audience, they may make your argument more persuasive. Use powerful visuals. At one point in his talk, Dan Pallotta uses pie charts to show the results of two nonprofits’ fundraising efforts. First, a bake sale with 5 percent overhead, and second, a professional fundraising enterprise with 40 percent overhead. The second one looks terrible, wasteful, until Dan says: We confuse morality with frugality. We’ve all been taught that the bake sale with 5 percent overhead is morally superior to the professional fundraising enterprise with 40 percent overhead, but we’re missing the most important piece of information, which is: What is the actual size of these pies? What if the bake sale only netted seventy-one dollars for charity because it made no investment in its scale, and the professional fundraising enterprise netted 71 million dollars because it did? Now which pie would we prefer, and which pie do we think people who are hungry would prefer?
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 1455-1458 | Added on Thursday, 26 May 2022 16:08:22

But wonder walks work best when there’s a clear linking theme. Something stronger than just a series of recent examples of your work. Without that, this type of talk can quickly become tedious. “Now we’ll turn to my next project” is a flat transition line that invites the audience to start shifting in their seats. Much stronger is to give us a link. “This next project took that idea and dialed it up by an order of magnitude . . .”

TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2028-2031 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 17:01:48

One temptation many speakers fall prey to is to use their slides as crutches. In the worst form, this means a series of dismal slides covered with text and bullet points that the speaker works through laboriously. Most people by now understand that this is a truly terrible way to give a talk. Every word you speak that someone has already seen on a slide is a word that carries zero punch. It’s not news anymore.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2038-2041 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 17:06:25

One thing to understand is that audiences really don’t mind one bit if you pause your talk for a moment to take stock. You might feel some discomfort. They won’t. The key is to be relaxed about it. When superstar DJ Mark Ronson came to TED2014, he was masterful at this. He lost his way at one point, but he simply smiled, walked over to a bottle of water, sipped it, told the audience this was his memory crutch, studied his notes, sipped again, and by the time he got going again, everyone liked him even more.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2222-2225 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 18:41:38

Audience attention is a truly precious commodity. You always have it when you first arrive on stage. Don’t fritter it away with small talk. It really, truly doesn’t matter that much that you are honored to be there, or that the organizer’s wife needs to be thanked. What matters is persuading the audience that they dare not switch off for a nanosecond. You want an opening that grabs people from the first moment. A surprising statement. An intriguing question. A short story. An incredible image.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2288-2291 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 19:02:54

How do you spark curiosity? The obvious way is to ask a question. But not just any question. A surprising question. How do we build a better future for all? Too broad. Too much of a cliché. I’m bored already. How did this fourteen-year-old girl, with less than $200 in her bank account, give her whole town a giant leap into the future? Now we’re talking.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2339-2341 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 19:11:17

Depending on what material you have, there are plenty of ways to ponder even more intriguing starts. “The image you’re about to see changed my life.” “I’m going to play you a video that, at first viewing, may seem to be
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2341-2344 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 19:11:25

impossible.” “Here’s my opening slide. Can you figure out what this thing is?” “Until two and a half months ago, no living human had cast eyes on this object.” Find the one that feels right for you. Compelling, but also authentic. An opening that will boost your own confidence going into the talk.

==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2344-2352 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 19:12:32

4. Tease, but don’t give it away Occasionally, speakers try to bring too much to their opening paragraph. They essentially give away the punchline of their talk. “Today I’m going to explain to you that the key to success as an entrepreneur is simply this: determination.” A worthy goal. But the speaker may have already lost the audience. They think they know the talk already. Even if what follows is full of nuance, logic, passion, and persuasion, they may no longer be listening. Suppose instead the talk started this way: “Over the next few minutes I plan to reveal what I believe is the key to success as an entrepreneur, and how anyone here can cultivate it. You’ll find clues to it in the story I’m about to tell.” You’ll probably give that speaker at least a few more minutes of your attention. So instead of giving it all away up front, imagine what kind of language will seduce the audience into wanting to come along for the ride.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2353-2354 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 19:14:30

“Let’s go for a hike. We’ll get to see a beautiful view of the valley.”

TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2357-2358 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 19:15:01

In the opening sentences your sole goal is to give your audience a reason to step away from their comfort zone and accompany you on an amazing journey of discovery.

TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)

You don’t have to show the shark, but we do need to know it’s coming. Every talk needs mapping—a sense of where you’re going, where you are, and where you’ve been. If your listeners don’t know where they are in the structure of the talk, they will quickly get lost.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2391-2407 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 19:21:26

Here’s how not to end: “Well, that’s my time gone, so I’ll wrap up there.” (You mean, you had a lot more to say but can’t tell us because of bad planning?) “Finally, I just want to thank my awesome team, who are pictured here: David, Joanna, Gavin, Samantha, Lee, Abdul, and Hezekiah. Also, my university, and my sponsors.” (Lovely, but do you care about them more than your idea, and more than us, your audience?!) “So, given the importance of this issue, I hope we can start a new conversation about it together.” (A conversation?! Isn’t that a little lame? What should be the outcome of that conversation?) “The future is full of challenges and opportunities. Everyone here has it in their heart to make a difference. Let’s dream together. Let’s be the change we want to see in the world.” (Beautiful sentiment, but the clichés really don’t help anyone.) “I’ll close with this video which summarizes my points.” (No! Never end with a video. End with you!) “So that concludes my argument, now are there any questions?” (Or, how to preempt your own applause.) “I’m sorry I haven’t had time to discuss some of the major issues here, but hopefully this has at least given you a flavor of the topic.” (Don’t apologize! Plan more carefully! Your job was to give the best talk you could in the time available.) “In closing, I should just point out that my organization could probably solve this problem if we were adequately funded. You have it in your power to change the world with us.” (Ah, so this was
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2407-2410 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 19:21:31

a fundraising pitch all along?) “Thanks for being such an amazing audience. I have loved every moment, standing here, talking to you. I’ll carry this experience with me for a long, long time. You’ve been so patient, and I know that you’ll take what you’ve heard today and do something wonderful with it.” (“Thank you” would have been just fine.)

TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2415-2417 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 19:21:58

Here are seven better ways to end: Camera pull-back You’ve spent the talk explaining a particular piece of work. At the end, why not show us the bigger picture, a broader set of possibilities implied by your work?

==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2452-2456 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 19:37:06

Teaching and learning should bring joy. How powerful would our world be if we had kids who were not afraid to take risks, who were not afraid to think, and who had a champion? Every child deserves a champion, an adult who will never give up on them, who understands the power of connection, and insists that they become the best that they can possibly be. Is this job tough? You betcha. Oh God, you betcha. But it is not impossible. We can do this. We’re educators. We’re born to make a difference. Thank you so much.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2420-2425 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 19:37:34

Just imagine an astronaut being able to feel the overall health of the International Space Station, or, for that matter, having you feel the invisible states of your own health, like your blood sugar and the state of your microbiome, or having 360-degree vision or seeing in infrared or ultraviolet. So the key is this: As we move into the future, we’re going to increasingly be able to choose our own peripheral devices. We no longer have to wait for Mother Nature’s sensory gifts on her timescales, but instead, like any good parent, she’s given us the tools that we need to go out and define our own trajectory. So the question now is, how do you want to go out and experience your universe?
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2428-2430 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 19:37:41

Give it away. Share it with people, because the people who can use it the most are the ones with no resources and no technology and no status and no power. Give it to them because they can do it in private. They need their bodies, privacy, and 2 minutes, and it can significantly change the outcomes of their life.

TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 2461-2464 | Added on Friday, 27 May 2022 19:40:03

I look at affairs from a dual perspective: hurt and betrayal on one side, growth and self-discovery on the other—what it did to you, and what it meant for me. And so when a couple comes to me in the aftermath of an affair that has been revealed, I will often tell them this: Today in the West, most of us are going to have two or three relationships or marriages, and some of us are going to do it with the same person. Your first marriage is over. Would you like to create a second one together?

==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)
- Your Highlight at location 3152-3156 | Added on Saturday, 28 May 2022 17:07:07

As TED developed, he began giving speakers shorter and shorter time slots. And he simply walked on stage and cut people off if they went on too long. He also banned audience questions, on the grounds that it would be more interesting to cram in another speaker than hear some audience member promote his own business under the guise of asking a question. This may have been really annoying to a few individuals, but for the audience experience overall, it was a godsend. It made for a fast-moving program. You could put up with the occasional dud talk because you knew it would be over soon.
==========
TED Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking (Chris Anderson)

“The secret of happiness is: find something more important than you are, and dedicate your life to it.”
==========
麦肯锡教我的工作方法 (安宅和人)
- Your Highlight at location 138-144 | Added on Sunday, 29 May 2022 21:30:32

所谓工作，是“为了产生什么成果而存在”。进行那些“已经知道不会产生变化的行动”，只是浪费时间而已。如果没有明确认清这一点，就很容易将“烦恼”错认为“思考”，宝贵的时间就这么流逝了。 因此，我总是提醒自己周围的人：“一旦发现自己正在烦恼，就马上停下、立刻休息，并且培养能够察觉自己正在烦恼的能力。”其原因是，“以你们这么聪明的头脑，不只十分认真，而是超级认真地思考，仍然想不明白的话，就请先停止思考这件事会比较好，因为你很可能已经陷于烦恼之中了”。虽然乍看之下可能会觉得很无聊，但意识到“烦恼”与“思考”的差别，对于想要“交出有价值成果”的人而言是非常重要的事情。毕竟在职场与研究中需要的是“思考”，自然必须以“能够找出答案”为前提。
==========
麦肯锡教我的工作方法 (安宅和人)
- Your Highlight at location 132-133 | Added on Sunday, 29 May 2022 21:30:52

思考与烦恼看起来很像，但是实际上完全不同。 所谓“
==========
麦肯锡教我的工作方法 (安宅和人)
- Your Highlight at location 198-202 | Added on Sunday, 29 May 2022 21:33:37

·“解决问题”之前，要先“查明问题”。 ·“提升答案的质量”并不够，“提升议题的质量”更重要。 ·不是“知道越多越聪明”，而是“知道太多会变笨”。 ·与其“快速做完每一件事”，不如“删减要做的事”。 ·与其计较“数字多寡”，不如计较“到底有没有答案”。
==========
麦肯锡教我的工作方法 (安宅和人)
- Your Highlight at location 465-475 | Added on Sunday, 29 May 2022 21:45:04

世界上的人大致可以分为两种：“视觉思考型”（即用视觉上的意象进行思考的类型）与“语言思考型”（即用语言进行思考的类型）。我是典型的视觉思考型的人，相应的，由于日本人使用汉字，因此多数人都属于视觉思考型。 将议题诉诸语言或转化为文字，对“视觉思考型”的人而言，尤其重要。 视觉思考型的人大致可以理解语言思考型的人所说的内容，但相反的，视觉思考型的人所说的内容对语言思考型的人来说则几乎全都无法理解。世界上属于语言思考型的人占多数，所以视觉思考型的人若不能对自己打算处理的议题加以语言化，将大幅降低团队的生产力。 我在刚进入职场的时候也是如此，虽然脑中浮现了许多点子，却无法将点子落实成语言，想说的话无法顺利传达给周围的人们，因而受了很多苦。但当我有意识地反复提醒自己“将议题转化为语言或文字”之后，过了一段时期工作忽然就变得轻松起来。 听起来好像很容易，然而一旦要实际执行，就会发现知易行难，这并不是那么简单的事情。不用语言或文字明确表达是许多人的思考习惯，所以我建议各位读者，必须刻意进行自我训练。
==========
发现你的销售力量

How Women Rise (Sally Helgesen)
- Your Highlight at location 935-938 | Added on Tuesday, 31 May 2022 19:15:09

If you’re considering how you might promote yourself, it helps to bear in mind that you are your primary product. As you talk about what you have achieved, you are always selling you—not just the details but the overall package. Every successful salesperson knows this. People buy because they like and trust you. And because they believe what you offer may have value for them. Why do they believe this? Because you so obviously do! Mesmerizing belief is the secret of every great salesperson.
==========
How Women Rise (Sally Helgesen)
- Your Highlight at location 938-941 | Added on Tuesday, 31 May 2022 19:16:13

To sell yourself effectively, therefore, believing in what you have to offer is essential. If Coke is doing a marketing campaign, they don’t say, “Well, some people prefer Pepsi. Or, it’s possible that, if you give Coke a try, you might like it.” No. Their job is to talk about how great Coke is. Not to hedge, but to come out and tell the world, “We’ve got a fantastic product.”

How Women Rise (Sally Helgesen)
- Your Highlight at location 1192-1196 | Added on Tuesday, 31 May 2022 19:37:48

The third kind of power is the power of personal authority or charisma, which is rooted in the confidence you inspire in others. You rarely start your career with much personal authority; it builds as your reputation develops over time. Expertise and connections can help establish personal authority, but there’s always another element: a strong presence, a distinctive cast of mind, a way of speaking and listening that inspires loyalty and trust, or an unusual degree of gravitas. Personal authority is what sets the most successful leaders apart, whether or not their authority is tied to position.

It’s about being clear, relevant, and succinct—crafting your message in a way that’s easy for the other person to understand, absorb, and remember.

As We Speak (Peter Meyers)
- Your Highlight at location 209-213 | Added on Saturday, 25 June 2022 15:58:15

Most of us make our first mistake in communication before we ever open our mouths. We assume that the listener cares about what we want to say. But they don’t. Not because they’re selfish or bad people. It’s just that each person’s favorite subject is himself. And the question the listener is asking, as soon as you begin to speak, is: “What’s in it for me?” Still, most of us will go into a difficult conversation and stubbornly insist on talking about what we want to say.

As We Speak (Peter Meyers)
- Your Highlight at location 232-235 | Added on Saturday, 25 June 2022 16:02:06

We say that speaking is an “inside job.” After working with thousands of people across the world, it has become clear to us that generally the problem isn’t outside, it’s inside. Rarely do we come across someone who needs “vocal training.” Your voice is fine. Your hands are fine. For decades, you’ve been using them to communicate effectively with other people. The question is, what are you doing inside your head that makes you behave unnaturally when you’re in the spotlight?
==========
As We Speak (Peter Meyers)
- Your Highlight at location 248-251 | Added on Saturday, 25 June 2022 16:03:47

These days, trust is the highest currency. The level of trust that you win or lose is directly proportionate to the quality of your communication. We decide very quickly whether or not we trust someone, based not only on the information they give us but on the way they say it. You may have the best data in the world, but if your body language doesn’t match your message, your listener will instinctively distrust what you say.

The good news is that there are only three things you have to master in High Performance Communication. They are: 1. Content. 2. Delivery. 3. State.
==========
As We Speak (Peter Meyers)
- Your Bookmark at location 353 | Added on Saturday, 25 June 2022 16:36:29
